messageBody:
> First: I take this post as a confession that in the previous
threads about TDD
> vs. DBC you really didn't know what you were talking of, because
if you were,
> you wouldn't ask such questions but instead respond to my posts on
these
> threads to continue argueing for DBC. The reason for that is not
so obvious
> to me. I think positive, so I don't think you're a troll, I think
it was your
> way to find out how DBC and TDD interact - just say something
you're not
> really convinced of yourself but hold that view to see what
arguments are
> against it. Please, next time just ask for these arguments instead
of
> behaving like a time sink.

Its strange that this forum uses censorship system before the
postings appear.
Must be a hot-headed community of JUnit users because this is
necessary.

I was and am serious, all the time.

Forget now about DbC. We can discuss about it later (in a few
weeks/month) again.

> Now to your questions:
> > Does the framework has to provide mock objects for JUnit tests?
> No, it's not required that the framework provides the mock
objects. But it
> would be helpful.

Somehow I can't imagine to use Mock objects without our framework to
support it.
We are at the beginning in our company of creating ERP applications
with the
framework and the know how is not good yet.

> > Is it possible to use Mock objects when using a ERP framework?
> That depends on wether the framework deserves the name framework
or not.
> A real framework consists of two parts: The API/SPI and the
implementation. If
> the framework is a real framework, you could simply implement the
API/SPI
> yourself to create mock objects and replace the implementation.

What means SPI?

>
> But your questions do not provide the information *where* and
*why* you want
> to use Mock objects. So you program using the ERP API yourself? Or
is it just
> a code generation tool like Versata?

Our programs use the ERP framework API. It is no code generation
tool.
The framework is very large and complex and still they work on it.
It is a
business framework which uses a component model and sits on top of
EJB.

I just want to use Mock objects for the database. The test data must
be coming
from the test classes and not be inside the database. So we need
Mock objects
I think. But I don't know how to create them since I still don't
know how
our framework works inside and how Mock objects are used.

Now you think it is not necessary that our framework supports Mock
objects?
